   604→Addons Integration � Key attributes
   605→AttributeWhy it mattersExample ruleAvailability windowPrevents overpromising and enables ops planningPrebooked (?24h); Sameday (?2h); Lastminute (<2h)Pricing modelControls revenue and driver incentivesStandard price; Lastminute = 2x standardValidation levelEnsures safety and legal compliance for special needsSelfdeclare; Agent verification; Documentation requiredResource bindingGuarantees physical items (child seat, ramp) are presentReserve kit to vehicle on dispatch; decrement inventoryAudit trailEnables refunds, disputes, and QATicketed addon with timestamps, staff ID, photosSLA for fulfillmentSets expectations for customers and opsConfirm within 15 minutes; deliver or refund within 30 minutes of ETA
   606→1. Overview and principles
   607→Treat addons as discrete SKU[E39]like items that must be reserved, validated, and auditable.
   608→Preserve safety and dignity: specialneeds requests require higher validation and documented handling steps.
   609→Lastminute requests (double price) are honored only when resources and safety checks permit[E40]; autodecline when unavailable.
   610→All addon transactions create or update an incident/booking ticket [E41]with full audit metadata.
   611→
   612→2. Offer catalogue and availability rules
   613→Define catalog items: Child Seat, Priority Pickup, Heated Seats, Water + Snack Kit, Wheelchair Ramp / Access, Assistance (mobility/visual), Extra Luggage.
   614→Availability windows: 
   615→Prebook (recommended): any time before 24 hours; guaranteed if reserved.
   616→Sameday: available if inventory or staff present; require confirmation within 15 minutes.
   617→Lastminute (<2h): allowed at double price (2� standard) only if dispatch confirms resource; otherwise autooffer nearest alternative or refund.
   618→Inventory binding: when confirmed, decrement hub inventory and attach resource ID to booking.
   619→
   620→3. Booking flows and UI/phone scripts
   621→Prebook flow (app, web, partner)
   622→Customer selects addon; system checks inventory & constraints; holds resource for a short reservation window (e.g., 15 min) [E42]while payment completes.
   623→On payment success: issue confirmation, attach addon SKU to booking, reserve driver with tag and checklist item.
   624→Sameday / lastminute flow (app, kiosk, phone)
   625→Customer requests addon. System performs realtime availability check and quotes price.
   626→If request is <2 hours before pickup, price shown = 2� standard and labeled LastMinute Guarantee.
   627→Require driver/dispatch confirmation within 10�15 minutes. If no confirmation, autorefund and notify customer with apology and alternative options.
   628→All confirmations update the ticket with responder ID and timestamp.
   629→Phone/kiosk agent script (concise)
   630→Verify Booking ID and customer identity.
   631→Inform price and TTL[E43]: �This addon is available at 2� the standard rate for lastminute requests; we will confirm within 15 minutes.�
   632→If customer accepts, process payment and escalate to dispatch for resource binding; log agent name and verification steps.
   633→
   634→4. Special needs handling (mobility, medical, accessibility)
   635→Tiered validation: 
   636→Low risk (extra luggage, heated seats): selfdeclare.
   637→Medium risk (child seat): require confirmation of child presence and age; driver must confirm on pickup.
   638→High risk (wheelchair assistance, medical equipment): require preapproval by Customer Support or medical documentation for recurring highimpact requests; sameday requests require supervisor approval.
   639→Dedicated resource pool: maintain a roster of vehicles equipped with ramps, tiedowns, and staff trained for assistance; bind these resources when booking.
   640→Nondiscrimination & dignity: staff wording templates for offers and denials; never refuse service solely on cost�offer alternatives (partner vehicle, scheduled pickup).
   641→Safety checklist: for every assisted pickup, driver completes a digital checklist: verify device compatibility, securement points, passenger comfort, and contact emergency protocol if needed; photo evidence optional with consent.
   642→Escalation: if onscene condition differs (equipment incompatible), driver must escalate to Shift Lead and provide immediate alternative transport or refund.
   643→
   644→5. Dispatch, driver workflow, and KPIs
   645→Dispatch tags: bookings with addons get structured tags[E44] (e.g., FAMILY_BUNDLE, LAST_MIN_DOUBLE, ACCESS_WHEELCHAIR). Drivers see tag, resource needs, and required checklist items.
   646→Driver confirmation: driver [E45]must accept within defined SLA and confirm resource on approach (photo or check mark).
   647→Failover rules: if driver cannot fulfill, dispatch immediately reassigns or issues instant refund/credit and notifies customer within 5 minutes.
   648→Incentives: pay drivers a fixed supplement for addon fulfillment plus a lastminute premium to encourage acceptance.
   649→KPIs to track: 
   650→Addon fulfillment rate (%)
   651→Lastminute acceptance SLA (minutes)
   652→Special needs successful fulfillment (%)
   653→Refund rate for failed addons (%)
   654→Customer satisfaction (postride NPS for addon bookings)

   656→6. Pricing, refunds, and dispute handling
   657→Transparent pricing: show base and lastminute price explicitly with TTL and confirmation requirement.
   658→Autorefund rules: 
   659→If dispatch fails to confirm within SLA, refund or credit automatically.
   660→If driver arrives without required resource, issue immediate refund + discount voucher as goodwill.
   661→Dispute evidence: attach driver acceptance logs, photos, and timestamps to ticket; require proof for refunds beyond automatic rules.
   662→Fraud controls: limit number of autoapproved lastminute doubleprice purchases per account per day; flag unusual patterns.
   663→
   664→7. Compliance, training, and audit
   665→Training: mandatory modules for child seat handling, wheelchair securement, dignity & communication, and addon payment flows. Refresher every 6 months.
   666→Scripts & templates: agent phone scripts, driver checklists, customer-facing copy for confirmations and denials.
   667→Audit trail: every addon transaction and access to specialneeds info recorded[E46] with staff ID and reason. Periodic audits of records and CCTV (where appropriate) for disputes.

   685→Goals and UX principles

   688→UX rules: keep replies short (1�2 sentences), localized (Amharic first, English fallback), name the passenger when available, reference the specific service or staff (driver/concierge), and include a simple CTA (rate again, share, or contact ops).

   703→NLP approach and architecture
   704→Tiered system 
   705→Lightweight classifier: detect sentiment, intent, and named entities (passenger name, staff ID, booking ID).

   843→Key benefits

If using Gmail API you can update labels; rewriting the original subject is possible only via provider APIs.

   852→from imapclient import IMAPClient
   853→import pyzmail

   860→SMTP_HOST=os.getenv("SMTP_HOST"); SMTP_PORT=int(os.getenv("SMTP_PORT") or 587)

   864→  "security": ["security","assault","theft","suspicious","unsafe","security breach","robbed"],

   870→def find_matches(text):
   871→  found=set()
   872→  t=text.lower()
   873→  for tag, words in KEYWORDS.items():

   879→def process_mail():
   880→  with IMAPClient(IMAP_HOST) as client:
   881→    client.login(IMAP_USER,IMAP_PASS)
   882→    client.select_folder('INBOX')
   883→    messages = client.search(['UNSEEN'])
   884→    for msgid, data in client.fetch(messages, ['ENVELOPE','BODY[]']).items():
   885→      raw = data[b'BODY[]']
   886→      msg = pyzmail.PyzMessage.factory(raw)
   887→      subj = msg.get_subject() or ""
   888→      sender = msg.get_addresses('from')[0][1] if msg.get_addresses('from') else "unknown"
   889→      body = msg.text_part.get_payload().decode(msg.text_part.charset) if msg.text_part else (msg.html_part.get_payload().decode(msg.html_part.charset) if msg.html_part else "")
   890→      matches = find_matches(subj + " " + body)
   891→      if matches:
   892→        tags = ",".join(matches)
   893→        new_subject = subj if subj.startswith("[URGENT]") else "[URGENT] " + subj

   895→        forward = EmailMessage()

   897→        forward['To'] = OPS_EMAIL

   899→        forward.set_content(f"Auto OPS alert\nOriginal sender: {sender}\nMatched: {tags}\n\n--- Original message ---\n{body}")
   900→        try:

   902→            s.starttls(); s.login(SMTP_USER, SMTP_PASS); s.send_message(forward)
   903→          logging.info(f"Alert sent for msgid {msgid} sender {sender} tags {tags}")
   904→        except Exception as e:

   910→        except Exception as e:

10 Reasons to Choose Shuttle Plus(Value Proposition)	
On-time guarantee 
We schedule around flight times, buffer for delays, and provide real-time updates so you get picked up and dropped off when you need to be.
Fixed transparent pricing 
Fares are clear upfront with no surge pricing, hidden fees, or unexpected airport surcharges.
Verified drivers and fleet standards 
Every driver is background-checked, trained to company safety standards, and operates maintained, brandstandard vehicles.
Consistent customer experience 
Uniformed drivers, branded vehicles, and scripted service moments ensure the same reliable experience every trip.
Seamless flight-aware logistics 
We monitor flight[E1] status, automatically adjust pickup windows, and proactively reassign drivers when flights are delayed or canceled.
Priority airport handling 
Dedicated dispatch and driver staging near terminals reduce wait times compared with general ride-hailing queues.
Corporate and group capabilities 
Easy group bookings, corporate billing, and reporting make Shuttle Plus efficient for teams and high-volume needs.
Accountability and traceability 
Each trip has an auditable booking trail, driver ID, and incident workflow so issues are resolved quickly and transparently.
Integrated partner experience 
Hotel and travel partner integrations let guests book in-room or during booking flow with pre-filled pickup details and reconciled commissions.
Product features that reduce friction 
Flight-aware booking, promo controls, partner codes, and server-side attribution reduce booking errors, fraud, and customer support load.

Direct comparisons
Airport rideshare and low-cost fares
Low sticker price often means unpredictable waits, surge pricing, and drivers unfamiliar with airport procedures. Shuttle Plus removes that variability with scheduled, flight-aware pickups, dedicated staging, and fixed fares so total door-to-door time and cost are predictable.
Hotel shuttles
Hotel shuttles are limited to specific hotels, runs, and often operate on fixed timetables. Shuttle Plus offers on-demand, bookable transfers from any address, partner hotel integrations for convenience, and revenue-share [E2]models that benefit hotels without restricting guest choice.
Taxis and local transport
Taxis can be immediate but vary widely in quality, safety, and price; they rarely provide corporate reconciliation, auditing trails[E3], or group booking at scale. Shuttle Plus couples reliability and scale with controls and reporting needed by businesses and frequent travelers.

Operational and commercial advantages
Lower hidden total cost of ownership for corporate programs because of fewer missed flights, fewer customer service exceptions, and simplified reconciliation.
Better guest satisfaction and NPS[E4] from consistent, branded service that reflects well on partners.
Scalable partner mechanics (one-pager, pilot terms, commission automation) that make partnership activation fast and measurable.
Risk reduction through driver vetting, vehicle maintenance logs, insurance alignment, and incident response playbooks.

Final summary
Choose Shuttle Plus when predictable timing, transparent pricing, branded reliability, partner integration, and auditable operations matter more than the lowest possible fare.



About ShuttlePlus[E5]
ShuttlePlus provides dependable, professional airport transfer and scheduled shuttle services designed for travelers, hotels, and corporate clients who value punctuality, safety, and a branded guest experience.

Mission[E6]
Deliver worryfree doortodoor airport transfers and route services by combining disciplined operations, clear communication, and technology that keeps riders and partners informed every step of the way.

Vision
Be the trusted transport partner for airports, hotels, and businesses across the region by building a scalable, auditready operation that turns repeat routes into reliable revenue and predictable service.

What We Do
Airport Transfers � Scheduled [E7]and ondemand rides timed to flight schedules with realtime tracking and driver ETA updates.
Corporate Shuttle Services � Contracted routes and staff transport with monthly invoicing and SLA reporting.
Hotel and Partner Programs � Whitelabel[E8] pickup for guest arrivals and departures, partner billing, and guest communications.
Event and Group Transfers � Coordinated group logistics with dedicated vehicles and onsite coordination.

How We Operate
Operational discipline � Daily vehicle readiness checks, driver briefings[E9], and documented runbooks for bookings, incidents, and manual dispatch.
Data driven � KPI tracking for utilization, ontime performance, and customer feedback to continuously improve routes and pricing.
Flexible technology � Simple booking flow, driver confirmations via app or WhatsApp, SMS notifications, and a lightweight dispatch dashboard for realtime visibility.
Pilot-first approach � We validate routes with short pilots to prove unit economics before scaling.

Safety and Compliance
Vetted drivers with background checks and ongoing training.
Commercial insurance and necessary permits for all vehicles.
Maintenance protocols and daily inspection checklists to ensure vehicle roadworthiness.
Incident reporting and escalation procedures that prioritize customer safety and fast resolution.

Our Values
Reliability � We show up on time and keep our promises.
Transparency � Clear pricing, concise communication, and regular performance reports.
Safety � Nonnegotiable standards for drivers, vehicles, and procedures.
Partnership � We integrate with hotels and businesses to make transportation effortless for their guests and staff.
Continuous improvement � We measure, learn, and iterate to reduce cost and increase satisfaction.

The Team
Shuttle Plus is led by a handson operations founder with deep experience in building auditready HR and operational systems and a small team focused on driving reliability, safety, and partner success. We partner with local vehicle leasing providers, experienced drivers, and technology vendors to deliver consistent service without heavy upfront capital.

Partner With Us
We run short pilots to prove value before scaling. To discuss a partnership, pilot, or corporate program, contact our operations team and we will prepare a tailored proposal and timeline.

Accident Operations Procedures � use of recordings for incidents
Purpose
Provide clear, auditable procedures for responding to vehicle accidents and incidents, using onboard recordings (dashcam, incab audio), CCTV, phone call logs, and app telemetry as primary evidence. Ensure passenger and staff safety, preserve evidence, comply with legal and privacy obligations, and deliver timely operations, insurance, and regulatory responses.

Scope and applicability
Applies to all Shuttle Plus vehicles, drivers, concierge staff, dispatchers, Ops Leads, and partner fleets.
Covers accidents, collisions, serious nearmisses, passenger injuries, and any incident where recordings (video, audio, telematics) may be relevant[E10].
Does not replace local legal reporting obligations; follow local emergency services and regulatory requirements first.

Key roles and responsibilities
Driver (on-scene): immediate safety, first aid, initial incident report to Dispatch.
On-scene Lead (senior driver or hub manager if present): coordinates passenger care and evidence protection[E11].
Dispatch / Operations Coordinator: receives incident report, activates Accident Response Team (ART), notifies relevant stakeholders, logs incident, and directs evidence capture.
ART (Operations Lead + Safety Officer + Legal/Compliance + Fleet Manager[E12]): manages escalation, evidence handling, police liaison, insurer notification, and PR/communication.
Evidence Custodian (Designated by Ops Lead): secures and maintains chain of custody for recordings and physical evidence.
Customer Care: manages passenger communication, welfare follow-up, and official complaint/claim intake.
Maintenance/Recovery: arranges vehicle tow and secure storage.

Immediate on-scene actions (first 0�10 minutes)
Ensure personal and passenger safety: stop vehicle, hazard lights on, set warning triangle if safe.
Call emergency services immediately for serious injury or immediate danger; advise Dispatch[E13].
Triage and first aid[E14]: driver or trained staff provide first aid within competence; call for ambulance[E15] if needed.
Secure scene (if safe): prevent further movement of vehicles involved unless needed to prevent greater harm.
Protect evidence: do not power off dashcams; do not delete recordings; avoid moving cameras or unplugging devices unless required for safety.
Notify Dispatch via priority line with short facts: vehicle plate, booking ID, location (GPS), injuries, request for ART.
Take photos (phone) of scene, vehicle positions, and visible damage if safe to do so.

Immediate evidence preservation (critical)
Leave all on-board recording devices powered and connected. If power must be removed for safety, document reason and time.
If dashcam system automatically overwrites footage based on time or storage, request immediate transfer of relevant files to secure storage (see Evidence Handling).
Preserve telematics trace (GPS, speed, braking events) and export or snapshot live telemetry if possible.
Driver must not edit or attempt to modify recordings or logs. Any attempt to alter evidence must be reported and will be logged as an exception.

Notification and initial escalation (within 10 minutes)
Dispatch logs incident in incident system with preliminary classification (P1 = life/limb; P2 = serious; P3 = minor).
ART convenes within 15 minutes for P1/P2 incidents; within 60 minutes for P3 as needed.
Notify Ops Lead, Evidence Custodian, Legal/Compliance, and Fleet Manager.
For serious injuries or criminal elements (theft, assault), request driver to preserve passenger details and encourage witness statements; advise passenger to contact police immediately.[E16]

Evidence collection, handling and chain of custody
Evidence types to collect: 
Dashcam video (front/rear/cabin), incab audio, CCTV (hub/terminal), passenger phone recordings (if voluntarily provided), call logs, trip telemetry (speed, brakes, GEO), driver logs, maintenance records[E17], photos.
Evidence Custodian duties: 
Create an evidence record with unique evidence ID(s) and timestamp.
Export original recordings in readonly format (MP4/AVI with metadata) and compute checksum/hash for each file.[E18]
Store originals in a secure, accesscontrolled repository (on-prem or encrypted cloud) and mark as evidence.
Produce working copies for investigators/insurers; never alter originals.
Log every access: who, when, purpose, and action taken.
Chain of custody form (fields): 
Evidence ID | Type | Source device | Exported by | Date/time exported | Storage location | Hash value | Access log summary.
Retention: 
Retain original evidence for minimum period required by local law and company policy (recommended minimum: 90 days for minor; 2 years for P1/P2 or until claim resolution).
Legal holds: 
If police or insurer requests hold beyond retention, Evidence Custodian applies legal hold and documents the request.

Using recordings in incident response and communication
Internal use: ART uses recordings to reconstruct timeline, determine liability, improve training, and support insurance claims.
External sharing: Share recordings with police, insurers, or legal counsel only after verification and via secure transfer; require recipient acknowledgement and use of working copy only.
Passenger-provided recordings: Accept voluntarily supplied customer recordings; document consent to use for investigation or claims.
Redaction for privacy: When sharing publicly (e.g., press), redact personal identifiers and in-cab audio unless release is authorized by legal/compliance team.

Interaction with police and regulators
Immediately cooperate with emergency services and police; provide on-request evidence per lawful process (warrants, formal requests).
ART�s Legal/Compliance officer coordinates all legal disclosures and ensures evidence is preserved until official release.
For cross-jurisdiction incidents (airports or international passengers), coordinate with local authorities and, if necessary, embassy contacts[E19].

Medical response and passenger welfare
Prioritize passenger and driver medical needs: ambulance, clinic transfer, and documented medical referrals.
For significant injuries, arrange hospital transfer and an Ops representative to accompany if requested and safe.
Capture signed consent for medical information sharing (if patient able) or request next-of-kin contact details.
Log all medical expenses and actions taken for insurance and potential compensation.

Communication plan
On-scene: driver gives brief factual update to Dispatch only; no admission of fault.
Passenger-facing: Customer Care provides empathetic, factual updates and next steps; avoid speculation.
Internal: ART daily brief until resolution for P1/P2 incidents.
External/public: Only authorized spokesperson (Head of Ops or appointed Comms) issues public statements; use pre-approved template for media and social channels.
Sample immediate passenger message: �We are sorry you experienced this incident. Your safety is our priority. We have notified emergency services and our Operations team is on the way. Please look for [Driver name], vehicle [plate]. We will be in contact shortly with next steps.�

Insurance, claims and financial handling
Immediately notify insurer(s) with incident ID, booking ID, and available evidence package. Log insurer reference number.
For passenger claims: collect evidence, itemized damages, receipts, and police reports where applicable. Forward to insurer and Legal/Compliance.
For vehicle repair and recovery: arrange tow[E20] to approved facility and document chain of custody for vehicle. Obtain repair estimates and timeline.

Investigation, root-cause analysis and corrective actions
ART conducts root-cause analysis within 7 business days (or sooner for P1/P2). Use recordings and telematics to reconstruct events.
Produce an incident investigation report: timeline, parties involved, evidence summary, probable cause, corrective actions, and risk mitigation recommendations.
Implement corrective actions: driver retraining, vehicle maintenance changes, SOP updates[E21], or disciplinary procedures as required.
Share anonymized lessons learned across operations and add to training materials.

Use of recordings for training and QA
Redacted recordings and reconstructed timelines may be used in driver refresher trainings and safety briefings.
Maintain a secure training library of anonymized incidents for continuous improvement.
Track training completion and measurable KPIs after corrective actions (reduction in similar incidents).

Documentation and recordkeeping
Incident file contents: 
Incident report (driver statement), passenger statements, witness statements, police report, evidence checklist, exported recordings (originals & working copies), medical notes, insurer correspondence, repair estimates, ART investigation report, corrective action log.
Store incident files in secure, accesscontrolled system with retention policy and audit trail.

Privacy, consent and legal compliance
Inform passengers when recordings will be used for investigation and claims; obtain consent for sharing nonpublic personal data where possible.
Comply with local data protection laws for recording retention, access, and sharing. If law requires immediate disclosure or deletion, follow legal instructions and document actions.
Always redact or anonymize PII for internal training or public disclosures unless explicit consent or lawful basis exists.

Testing, drills and audits
Quarterly incident response drills that include evidence preservation and export steps (dashcam/CCTV retrieval, hash verification).
Annual audit of evidence handling and chain of custody logs.
Monthly spot checks of dashcam health, storage capacity, and overwrite settings[E22].

Tools, systems and technical requirements
Dashcam/Cabin audio devices must support timestamped, tamperevident exports and maintain system logs.
Telematics must record speed, brake events, and GPS traces with timestamps aligned to recordings (NTP[E23] sync recommended).
Evidence storage: encrypted, accesscontrolled repository; maintain checksums and access logs.
Incident management system: record incident ID, classification, evidence links, action items, and SLA[E24]-driven tasks.

Quick on-scene checklist (driver)
Ensure safety; call emergency services if needed.
Turn hazard lights on; set triangle if safe.
Keep recording devices powered; do not delete footage.
Call Dispatch; provide concise facts (plate, booking ID, GPS, injuries).
Take photos if safe; collect witness names/contact where possible.
Do not admit fault or speculate.
Follow Dispatch/ART instructions.

Quick evidence custodian checklist
Export original recordings immediately (if system allows) and compute hash.
Upload originals to secure evidence store; create working copy for investigators.
Complete chain of custody form; log all access.
Notify Legal/Compliance and Insurer; provide access to working copies only.
Apply legal hold [E25]if requested by authorities or insurer.

KPIs and monitoring
Evidence preservation SLA: all P1/P2 recordings exported and secured within 4 hours of incident.
Chain of custody completeness: 100% of incidents with signed forms.
Incident investigation completion: P1/P2 within 7 business days; P3 within 21 days.
Post-incident corrective action closure rate within 30 days.

Training and certification
All drivers: annual incident response and evidence preservation training; refresher every 6 months for high-risk routes.
Evidence Custodians and ART: certification on digital evidence handling and chain of custody procedures.
Dispatchers: annual scenario training [E26]for initial response, ART activation, and evidence preservation steps.

Review and update cadence
ART reviews procedures semi-annually or after any P1/P2 incident. Update SOPs, training, and technical configs as needed[E27].

Ad Template Integration and Style-Guide Enforcement
Purpose
Ensure every ad mock, draft, and live creative strictly follows Shuttle Plus brand standards and campaign rules so visual identity, messaging, and legal claims remain consistent across channels.

Template system and asset library
Create a single Master Template Library containing: approved layouts (desktop/mobile/video), color swatches (hex + usage), typography specs (font family, sizes, weights), logo lockups (variants and clear-space), icon set, badge assets, and legal/disclaimer blocks.
Store library in a versioned asset system (Figma/Adobe + cloud folder) with one canonical source [E34]and read-only access for creatives; grant edit rights only to Brand Manager and Design Lead.
Provide downloadable template files: PSD/AI (static), MP4/AE (video), Figma components, and HTML/CSS snippets for responsive landing assets.
Include a visual token file (CSS variables or JSON) that front-end and ad-build tools consume directly.

Mandatory template rules (applied to every mock)
Brand colors: use primary palette for CTA and accents; secondary palette only for backgrounds and subtext.
Logo: place approved logo variant; maintain minimum clear space and minimum display size; never use alternate colors unless in approved palette.
Typography: headline, subhead, body, and CTA use specified fonts and weights; do not substitute web-safe fonts without approval.
Imagery: use only pre-approved, tagged hero images; apply approved color grade/overlay and always include alt [E35]text.
CTA: use exact approved phrasing (e.g., Book Now, Get Quote); CTA color and microcopy must match template.

Option A : Self-hosted Python service (free, full control)
What it does

Key benefits

# requirements: pip install imapclient pyzmail36 python-dotenv requests
# .env holds IMAP_HOST, IMAP_USER, IMAP_PASS, SMTP_HOST, SMTP_PORT, SMTP_USER, SMTP_PASS, OPS_EMAIL

import os, re, time, logging
from imapclient import IMAPClient
import pyzmail
import smtplib
from email.message import EmailMessage
from dotenv import load_dotenv

load_dotenv()
IMAP_HOST=os.getenv("IMAP_HOST"); IMAP_USER=os.getenv("IMAP_USER"); IMAP_PASS=os.getenv("IMAP_PASS")
SMTP_HOST=os.getenv("SMTP_HOST"); SMTP_PORT=int(os.getenv("SMTP_PORT") or 587)
SMTP_USER=os.getenv("SMTP_USER"); SMTP_PASS=os.getenv("SMTP_PASS")
OPS_EMAIL=os.getenv("OPS_EMAIL","ops@shuttleplus.com")
KEYWORDS = {
  "security": ["security","assault","theft","suspicious","unsafe","security breach","robbed"],
  "luggage": ["lost luggage","missing bag","luggage","baggage lost","suitcase missing","baggage damage","lost bag"]
}
LOGFILE="ops_alert.log"
logging.basicConfig(filename=LOGFILE,level=logging.INFO,format="%(asctime)s %(message)s")

def find_matches(text):
  found=set()
  t=text.lower()
  for tag, words in KEYWORDS.items():
    for w in words:
      if w in t:
        found.add(tag); break
  return list(found)

def process_mail():
  with IMAPClient(IMAP_HOST) as client:
    client.login(IMAP_USER,IMAP_PASS)
    client.select_folder('INBOX')
    messages = client.search(['UNSEEN'])
    for msgid, data in client.fetch(messages, ['ENVELOPE','BODY[]']).items():
      raw = data[b'BODY[]']
      msg = pyzmail.PyzMessage.factory(raw)
      subj = msg.get_subject() or ""
      sender = msg.get_addresses('from')[0][1] if msg.get_addresses('from') else "unknown"
      body = msg.text_part.get_payload().decode(msg.text_part.charset) if msg.text_part else (msg.html_part.get_payload().decode(msg.html_part.charset) if msg.html_part else "")
      matches = find_matches(subj + " " + body)
      if matches:
        tags = ",".join(matches)
        new_subject = subj if subj.startswith("[URGENT]") else "[URGENT] " + subj
        # Forward alert
        forward = EmailMessage()
        forward['From'] = SMTP_USER
        forward['To'] = OPS_EMAIL
        forward['Subject'] = f"OPS_ALERT {new_subject} [{tags}]"
        forward.set_content(f"Auto OPS alert\nOriginal sender: {sender}\nMatched: {tags}\n\n--- Original message ---\n{body}")
        try:
          with smtplib.SMTP(SMTP_HOST, SMTP_PORT) as s:
            s.starttls(); s.login(SMTP_USER, SMTP_PASS); s.send_message(forward)
          logging.info(f"Alert sent for msgid {msgid} sender {sender} tags {tags}")
        except Exception as e:
          logging.error(f"Forward fail for msgid {msgid} error {e}")
        # Optionally add a custom header or move to OPS_ALERTS folder
        try:
          client.copy(msgid, 'OPS_ALERTS')
          client.add_flags([msgid], ['\\Seen'])
        except Exception as e:
          logging.warning("Folder copy failed: " + str(e))

if __name__ == "__main__":
  while True:
    try:
      process_mail()
    except Exception as e:
      logging.error("Processing error: "+str(e))
    time.sleep(30)

Aviation compliance for offairport baggage services[E59]
A thorough review of regulatory, operational, and compliance considerations for running offairport baggage services (e.g., curbside checkin, offsite bag drop, luggage delivery) with practical controls, implied responsibilities, and rollout checklist.

1. Applicable guidance and legal sources
IATA provides an offairport baggage operations playbook with recommendations on processes, roles, security, and chainofcustody controls for baggage handled away from the terminal IATA.[E60]
National regulators (example: Ethiopian CAA) publish groundoperations guidance that sets local compliance, documentation, and operational requirements; local rules take precedence over industry guidance ecaa.gov.et.
Airlines� Conditions of Carriage and baggage rules define commercial liability, acceptance criteria, and passenger notification requirements � you must align offairport processes to each carrier�s policies you serve Ethiopian Airlines.
ICAO and aviation assemblies also promote best practices for disrupted baggage handling and offairport delivery as a safety and passengerservice improvement area International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO).

2. Key compliance domains to cover
Regulatory approvals and notifications: confirm whether national CAA approval, groundhandling license amendments, or written permissions are required to operate offairport checkin, bag acceptance, storage, or delivery (including any station or municipal permits) ecaa.gov.et.
Airline agreements and SOP alignment: execute written agreements/MOUs with partner airlines that define acceptance criteria, liability limits, weight/size rules, prohibited items handling, and transfer handoff protocols Ethiopian Airlines.
Security & screening: ensure baggage presented offairport either has been screened to the same standard as onairport accepted bags or that a secure, approved screening and transfer path exists to the airport screening chain; document screening method and custody chain IATA.
Chain of custody & evidence: implement strict handoff records (tag IDs, timestamps, staff IDs, photos, signed receipts, hashes) so you can demonstrate who handled each item and when IATA ecaa.gov.et.
Data protection & privacy: collect minimal PII on devices/tags, secure storage, and obtain passenger consent; align retention with local law and airline requirements Ethiopian Airlines.
Insurance & liability: obtain appropriate commercial liability and cargo insurance that covers offairport acceptance, intransit loss, damage, and thirdparty claims; ensure policy limits align with airline contract terms and national liability rules Ethiopian Airlines.
Customs and crossborder rules: if bags will cross borders (e.g., delivered to an international destination), confirm customs declaration, export/import control, and passenger declaration requirements and permit handling by your staff or partner forwarder International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO).
Incident reporting & escalation: define immediate reporting timelines for lost/damaged/stolen baggage to airline partners and regulator, and preserve evidence for claims and investigations ecaa.gov.et.

3. Operational controls and procedures
Acceptance checklist: require staff to verify booking ID, passenger identity, routing, tag/label issuance, allowed items checklist, and a signed digital handoff receipt with timestamp and photo evidence IATA.
Tagging and unique IDs: use tamperresistant tags with unique IDs that are recorded against booking and staff IDs; log scans at each transfer point and on arrival at the airport to maintain reconciliation IATA.
Secure storage & transport: dedicated storage areas with controlled access, CCTV, inventory reconciliation at shift changes, sealed containers for transport, and documented chainofcustody seals for highvalue items ecaa.gov.et.

  1877→Data Protection Policy Plan � App and Database Compliance (Shuttle Plus)
  1878→Purpose
  1879→Define the governance, controls and operational steps Shuttle Plus will apply to protect customer and employee personal data processed by the mobile app, backend databases and supporting services so the company meets Ethiopia�s PDPP, applicable sector rules (e.g., PCI DSS for payments) and international best practice.
  1880→
  1881→1. Scope and Applicability
  1882→Scope: All personal data collected, stored, processed or transmitted by Shuttle Plus systems (mobile apps, APIs, backend databases, analytics, payment flows, CRM, logs, thirdparty services).
  1883→Data subjects: Customers, drivers, employees, contractors, suppliers.
  1884→Processing activities covered: Registration/KYC, booking and routing, telemetry (GPS), payments, customer support, marketing, profiling, background checks.
  1885→Exemptions: Aggregated anonymised data used for analytics (only after formal verification of irreversibility).
  1886→
  1887→2. Governing Principles
  1888→Lawful, fair and transparent processing � document legal basis (consent, contract, legal obligation, legitimate interest) per processing activity.
  1889→Purpose limitation and minimisation � collect only necessary attributes and retain them only as required.
  1890→Accuracy � maintain capability for subjects to update or correct data.
  1891→Storage limitation � retention schedules defined by data class.
  1892→Integrity and confidentiality � technical and organisational protections against unauthorised access or loss.
  1893→Accountability � documented decisions, DPIAs, logs and audit trails.
  1894→
  1895→3. Roles and Governance
  1896→Data Protection Officer (DPO) / Privacy Lead: overall accountability for PDPP alignment, DPIAs, regulatory liaison and breach notification.
  1897→Data Controller: Shuttle Plus PLC (legal entity) � defines purposes.
  1898→Data Owners: Business unit leads (Product, Ops, Finance) � approve retention and access.
  1899→Data Stewards: Engineering/DBA, Security, Support � implement controls and operate processes.
  1900→Privacy Steering Committee: Legal, IT, Product, Ops, HR � monthly review of highrisk projects and incidents.
  1901→
  1902→4. Data Inventory and Lawful Basis Mapping
  1903→Create and maintain a live data map (data elements; source; flow diagram; storage locations; processors; retention period; legal basis).
  1904→Tag highrisk datasets: GPS telemetry, identity documents, payment card data, criminal/conviction checks. These require DPIA and elevated controls.
  1905→Classify data sensitivity: Public / Internal / Confidential / Highly Confidential; apply controls accordingly.
  1906→
  1907→5. Technical and Organisational Controls
  1908→Identity & Access Management 
  1909→RBAC with least privilege; enforce role separation and periodic access reviews.
  1910→MFA for admin and ops access; strong password policies.
  1911→Encryption & Key Management 
  1912→TLS for data in transit; AES256 (or equivalent) for PII at rest.
  1913→Dedicated key management (KMS) with separation of duties; rotate keys per policy.
  1914→Database Hardening 
  1915→Disable unused services; enforce parameterised queries; enable DBlevel encryption, rowlevel encryption for sensitive fields where appropriate.
  1916→Read replicas and backups encrypted and accessrestricted.
  1917→Network & Infrastructure 
  1918→Network segmentation (app tier, DB tier, admin), private subnets for databases, strict firewall rules.
  1919→WAF for APIs and rate limiting.
  1920→Logging, Monitoring & Detection 
  1921→Immutable audit logs for data access and administrative actions; central SIEM with alerting on anomalous access patterns.
  1922→Retain logs per legal/forensic needs; protect logs from tampering.
  1923→Application Security 
  1924→Secure coding standards; static and dynamic scanning in CI/CD; dependency vulnerability management.
  1925→Input validation, output encoding, and strict session management.
  1926→Payment Card Data 
  1927→Isolate cardholder environment; comply with PCI DSS controls (tokenisation, no storage of CVV, segmented networks).
  1928→Data Minimisation & Pseudonymisation 
  1929→Use pseudonymisation for analytics; store identifiers separately where feasible.
  1930→Backups & Resilience 
  1931→Encrypted backups, tested restore procedures and retention aligned to policy.
  1932→Vendor & ThirdParty Controls 
  1933→Written processor agreements (security obligations, audit rights, breach notification, subprocessor rules). Vendor security risk assessments and annual reassessments.
  1934→
  1935→6. Data Subject Rights and UX
  1936→Rights supported: Access, rectification, erasure, restriction, objection, portability, automated decision review.
  1937→Operational workflows: Selfservice portal for simple requests; authenticated support channel for complex requests. Verify identity before fulfilment; log requests and responses with timestamps to meet statutory SLAs.
  1938→Consent & Preference Management: Granular consent capture (profiling, marketing); store consent records with versioning; allow easy withdrawal.
  1939→
  1940→7. DPIA, Risk Assessment and Change Control
  1941→Mandatory DPIA for highrisk processing: GPS realtime tracking, profiling, largescale KYC, automated decisioning.
  1942→Threat modelling for new features; security/privacy signoff gate in product lifecycle.
  1943→Change control: every schema change or new thirdparty integration requires privacy/security review before deployment.
  1944→
  1945→8. Incident Response and Breach Notification
  1946→Incident response plan with defined roles (Incident Lead, Communications, Legal, Forensics, DPO).
  1947→Triage timeline: Initial containment within hours; 72hour regulator notification threshold for reportable breaches (or as specified by PDPP). Notify affected data subjects where likely risk to rights.
  1948→Forensics & remediation: Preserve evidence, rootcause analysis, corrective measures and postincident report to Steering Committee.
  1949→
  1950→9. Retention, Deletion and Archival
  1951→Retention schedule per data class (e.g., booking logs: 3 years; payment records for tax: statutory period; KYC: 5 years after relationship ends) � publish internal schedule and automate deletion where possible.
  1952→Secure deletion: use cryptographic erase or DB record purge; maintain tamperevident deletion logs.
  1953→Archival: encrypt and restrict archived datasets; limit access and periodically rereview necessity.
  1954→
  1955→10. CrossBorder Transfers
  1956→Default rule: Avoid transferring PD to jurisdictions without adequate protections.
  1957→When necessary: apply safeguards � regulator approvals, standard contractual clauses, Binding Corporate Rules or equivalent contractual commitments; document transfer legal basis in data map.
  1958→Data localisation: where permitted/required, use local processing and storage.
  1959→
  1960→11. Training, Awareness and Culture
  1961→Mandatory privacy & security training for all staff at onboarding and annually; rolebased advanced training for engineers, ops and customer support.
  1962→Simulations: tabletop breach exercises quarterly; phishing exercises for staff.
  1963→Reporting channels: anonymous reporting for suspected misuse with no retaliation.
  1964→
  1965→12. Monitoring, Audit and Continuous Improvement
  1966→KPIs: % of data mapped; DPIAs completed for highrisk features; mean time to detect (MTTD) and mean time to respond (MTTR) for incidents; DSAR SLA compliance; encryption coverage.
  1967→Audits: quarterly internal technical audits and annual external privacy/security audits (include PCI attestation where applicable).
  1968→Policy review cadence: Policy and data map reviewed at least annually or after significant legal/architectural change.

  1977→Publish user privacy notice and consent UI; implement consent storage.

  1979→Days 46�75
  1980→Integrate DSAR workflows (support portal + templates); implement retention automation for lowrisk data.
  1981→Vendor contractual updates and security questionnaires completed for top 10 vendors.
  1982→Implement SIEM alerting for abnormal DB access; schedule first tabletop breach exercise.
  1983→Days 76�90
  1984→Complete remediation actions from DPIAs; finalize backup encryption and tested restore.
  1985→Run internal audit of access rights; remediate excessive privileges.
  1986→Produce regulatorready documentation pack (data map, DPIAs, breach plan, vendor register).
  1987→14. Practical Controls Checklist (quick)
  1988→Enforce RBAC + MFA; periodic access review.
  1989→TLS everywhere; AES256 at rest; KMS for keys.
  1990→Parameterised queries + ORM protections; secrets management.
  1991→PCI tokenisation for cards; avoid storing CVV.

  1993→Vendor contracts with processors� obligations.

Secure storage & transport: dedicated storage areas with controlled access, CCTV, inventory reconciliation at shift changes, sealed containers for transport, and documented chainofcustody seals for highvalue items ecaa.gov.et.
Screening and transfer points: either perform screening at your offairport facility under approved procedures or guarantee a secured controlled transfer to airport screening within required timelines and documented handoff events IATA.
Evidence capture: attach photos of exterior condition, tag placement, and staff IDs; compute and record hashes for any digital artifacts (photo, signed receipt) for tamper evidence IATA.
Quality control & audits: run weekly reconciliation between accepted bags and delivered/boarded bags, and perform monthly spot audits and full inventory reconciliations with airline partners ecaa.gov.et.



4. Technology, tagging, and auditability
Tagging model: prefer a canonical tag URL/ID that maps to booking and staff records in your backend; support NFC/QR fallback and print batch tags with sequential IDs for auditability IATA.
Proof of receipt: capture a signed digital receipt (passenger signature + staff signature), attach photos, GPS at acceptance (where permitted), and store as PDF + immutable JSON payload in an audit store IATA.
System of record: keep a canonical, timeordered event log (accept, transfer, airport receive, exception) that is exportable for airline reconciliation and regulator audits ecaa.gov.et.
Nonrepudiation: compute SHA256 hashes of signed documents and request serverside cryptographic signing (KMS) to create a certificate of completion that can be validated in disputes IATA.

5. Staffing, training and human factors
Competency & vetting: staff must be backgroundchecked per airline/regulator rules, trained on prohibited items, secure handling, and customer data protection; maintain training records ecaa.gov.et.
SOPs & role clarity: define explicit SOPs for acceptance, screening, tagging, storage, transport, escalation, and incident handling; publish quickreference pocket cards and inapp guides for staff IATA.
Supervision and spot checks: shift leads must perform spot handoff observations and weekly reviews of logs and photos; escalate deviations immediately to operations manager and airline partner ecaa.gov.et.

6. Passenger notices, consent and liability language
Clear disclosure: provide passengers with clear, signed acknowledgement at acceptance covering service scope, liability limits, claims window, and contact/claims process (aligned to the airline�s Conditions of Carriage) Ethiopian Airlines IATA.
Booking & receipts: include booking ID, tag ID, expected delivery SLA, and claim reference on the digital/paper receipt; retain copies for audit and customer service resolution IATA.

Methodology and selection logic
I defined "comparable" as companies offering airport-to-hotel or point-to-point transfer services using an asset-light or mixed model (marketplace/OTA/contracted drivers or franchised shuttles) and operating across multiple countries or with global reach.
From that universe I selected 10+ operators known for cross-border reach, marketplace/OTA models, or recognizable brands in the airport transfer space.
I ranked candidates for case-study selection by breadth of geographic coverage, product/tech sophistication, and relevance to a global brand-scale Shuttle Plus. The top three chosen are GetTransfer, KiwiTaxi, and Welcome Pickups.

Case study 1 � GetTransfer
Company profile and positioning
GetTransfer operates as a global marketplace connecting travelers with local transfer providers and independent drivers. It positions itself as a flexible, price-competitive platform for on-demand and pre-booked transfers.
Business model and revenue streams
Commission-based marketplace: charges a percentage on each booking.
Tiered service levels: basic private cars to premium options and minibuses.
Cross-sell opportunities: extended journeys, hourly bookings, and multi-stop transfers.
Technology and operations
Centralized booking engine and dynamic pricing.
Supplier portal for drivers and partner operators [E68]to accept requests and manage schedules.
Customer-facing apps and web booking with instant confirmations and messaging.
Distribution and partnerships
Heavy reliance on direct consumer web traffic and OTAs.
Integrations with travel platforms and affiliate channels.
Local partnerships with drivers and small fleets rather than owning assets.
Strengths
Large global inventory and geographic reach.
Competitive pricing due to many suppliers competing for jobs.
Flexible service options (vehicle types, meet-and-greet).
Weaknesses / risks
Quality consistency varies by market because of heterogeneous supplier base.
Margin pressure from commission competition.
Customer support complexity across time zones and languages.
Strategic takeaways for Shuttle Plus
Use a marketplace model to rapidly scale inventory while maintaining a standardized minimum service SLA and training for suppliers.[E69]
Invest early in supplier vetting, standard operating procedures, and a certification program to reduce quality variance.
Differentiate on reliability and customer service rather than just price.

Expanded case study 1 � GetTransfer
Overview and strategic positioning
GetTransfer is an asset-light global marketplace that connects travelers with local drivers and small fleet operators. Its strategic play is rapid geographic coverage, broad vehicle choice, and price competitiveness achieved by aggregating many suppliers and enabling real-time matching between demand and local supply.
Business model and unit economics (per ride)
Revenue model: Commission on each booking (percentage of fare) + booking fees and surcharges for extras (meet-and-greet, wait time, child seat).
Typical unit revenue: Platform takes a commission (e.g., 20�35% of gross fare in mature marketplaces) and may add a fixed booking fee.
Direct variable costs: Payment processing fees; customer support cost allocated per ride; refunds/chargebacks; marketing CAC amortized per ride.
Contribution margin: Depends on commission rate and CAC; marketplaces often show positive contribution margin at scale because supplier pays drivers directly (low fixed cost on platform side). Expect a mid-to-high single digit to low double-digit percent contribution margin per ride before corporate overheads if CAC is managed.
Key unit drivers: Average order value (AOV) � influenced by distance and vehicle class; utilization of supply (idle time reduces supplier willingness to accept low-margin jobs); CAC efficiency; refund rate and cancellations.
Operations and quality control
Supplier onboarding: Lightweight verification (IDs, vehicle docs) with local partners self-managing fleets.[E73]
Quality variability: Heterogeneous supplier base causes uneven service; platform relies on ratings, reviews, and dispute resolution to manage quality.
Customer support: Centralized multi-language support plus automated messaging; real-time messaging between passenger and driver.
Flight tracking: Automatic flight delay handling with reallocation logic; crucial to reduce no-shows and wasted driver time.
Technology stack and features
Core components: Consumer booking site + mobile app; supplier portal; routing and dispatch matching engine; payment gateway; CRM and ticketing system.
Differentiators to scale: Dynamic pricing, instant confirmation, multi-stop bookings, and API partnerships with OTAs.
Data usage: Demand forecasting to seed supply; historical ETAs and pricing elasticity to set commission thresholds.
Distribution and marketing
Channels: Direct SEO/SEM, OTA/affiliate integrations, travel meta-search, and occasional corporate accounts.
Growth levers: Market liquidity (enough drivers to offer instant confirmation), local promotions to increase supply, and partnerships with high-volume travel sellers.
Strengths, weaknesses, and risks
Strengths: Rapid expansion, wide selection, price leadership, low capital intensity.
Weaknesses: Quality control issues; thin margins under price competition; reliance on many small suppliers complicates standardization.
Risks: Regulatory changes for drivers, localized competition that vertically integrates (own fleets), reputational risk from inconsistent experiences.
Scalability playbook recommendation for Shuttle Plus
Use a marketplace to enter many cities quickly but implement a layered supplier model: certified preferred partners in top markets; open marketplace elsewhere.
Define minimum service-level agreements (SLA) and financial incentives/penalties to enforce them.
Invest in centralized flight monitoring, automated re-dispatch, and a robust refund/compensation engine to protect customer experience without manual overhead.
Track unit economics tightly: AOV by market, CAC by channel, on-time rate, and supplier fill rate.

Data Protection Policy Plan � App and Database Compliance (Shuttle Plus)
Purpose
Define the governance, controls and operational steps Shuttle Plus will apply to protect customer and employee personal data processed by the mobile app, backend databases and supporting services so the company meets Ethiopia�s PDPP, applicable sector rules (e.g., PCI DSS for payments) and international best practice.

1. Scope and Applicability
Scope: All personal data collected, stored, processed or transmitted by Shuttle Plus systems (mobile apps, APIs, backend databases, analytics, payment flows, CRM, logs, thirdparty services).
Data subjects: Customers, drivers, employees, contractors, suppliers.
Processing activities covered: Registration/KYC, booking and routing, telemetry (GPS), payments, customer support, marketing, profiling, background checks.
Exemptions: Aggregated anonymised data used for analytics (only after formal verification of irreversibility).

2. Governing Principles
Lawful, fair and transparent processing � document legal basis (consent, contract, legal obligation, legitimate interest) per processing activity.
Purpose limitation and minimisation � collect only necessary attributes and retain them only as required.
Accuracy � maintain capability for subjects to update or correct data.
Storage limitation � retention schedules defined by data class.
Integrity and confidentiality � technical and organisational protections against unauthorised access or loss.
Accountability � documented decisions, DPIAs, logs and audit trails.

3. Roles and Governance
Data Protection Officer (DPO) / Privacy Lead: overall accountability for PDPP alignment, DPIAs, regulatory liaison and breach notification.
Data Controller: Shuttle Plus PLC (legal entity) � defines purposes.

Privacy Steering Committee: Legal, IT, Product, Ops, HR � monthly review of highrisk projects and incidents.

4. Data Inventory and Lawful Basis Mapping
Create and maintain a live data map (data elements; source; flow diagram; storage locations; processors; retention period; legal basis).
Tag highrisk datasets: GPS telemetry, identity documents, payment card data, criminal/conviction checks. These require DPIA and elevated controls.
Classify data sensitivity: Public / Internal / Confidential / Highly Confidential; apply controls accordingly.

5. Technical and Organisational Controls
Identity & Access Management 
RBAC with least privilege; enforce role separation and periodic access reviews.
MFA for admin and ops access; strong password policies.
Encryption & Key Management 
TLS for data in transit; AES256 (or equivalent) for PII at rest.
Dedicated key management (KMS) with separation of duties; rotate keys per policy.
Database Hardening 
Disable unused services; enforce parameterised queries; enable DBlevel encryption, rowlevel encryption for sensitive fields where appropriate.
Read replicas and backups encrypted and accessrestricted.
Network & Infrastructure 
Network segmentation (app tier, DB tier, admin), private subnets for databases, strict firewall rules.
WAF for APIs and rate limiting.
Logging, Monitoring & Detection 
Immutable audit logs for data access and administrative actions; central SIEM with alerting on anomalous access patterns.
Retain logs per legal/forensic needs; protect logs from tampering.
Application Security 
Secure coding standards; static and dynamic scanning in CI/CD; dependency vulnerability management.
Input validation, output encoding, and strict session management.
Payment Card Data 
Isolate cardholder environment; comply with PCI DSS controls (tokenisation, no storage of CVV, segmented networks).
Data Minimisation & Pseudonymisation 
Use pseudonymisation for analytics; store identifiers separately where feasible.
Backups & Resilience 
Encrypted backups, tested restore procedures and retention aligned to policy.
Vendor & ThirdParty Controls 
Written processor agreements (security obligations, audit rights, breach notification, subprocessor rules). Vendor security risk assessments and annual reassessments.

6. Data Subject Rights and UX
Rights supported: Access, rectification, erasure, restriction, objection, portability, automated decision review.
Operational workflows: Selfservice portal for simple requests; authenticated support channel for complex requests. Verify identity before fulfilment; log requests and responses with timestamps to meet statutory SLAs.
Consent & Preference Management: Granular consent capture (profiling, marketing); store consent records with versioning; allow easy withdrawal.

7. DPIA, Risk Assessment and Change Control
Mandatory DPIA for highrisk processing: GPS realtime tracking, profiling, largescale KYC, automated decisioning.
Threat modelling for new features; security/privacy signoff gate in product lifecycle.
Change control: every schema change or new thirdparty integration requires privacy/security review before deployment.

8. Incident Response and Breach Notification
Incident response plan with defined roles (Incident Lead, Communications, Legal, Forensics, DPO).
Triage timeline: Initial containment within hours; 72hour regulator notification threshold for reportable breaches (or as specified by PDPP). Notify affected data subjects where likely risk to rights.
Forensics & remediation: Preserve evidence, rootcause analysis, corrective measures and postincident report to Steering Committee.

9. Retention, Deletion and Archival
Retention schedule per data class (e.g., booking logs: 3 years; payment records for tax: statutory period; KYC: 5 years after relationship ends) � publish internal schedule and automate deletion where possible.
Secure deletion: use cryptographic erase or DB record purge; maintain tamperevident deletion logs.
Archival: encrypt and restrict archived datasets; limit access and periodically rereview necessity.

10. CrossBorder Transfers
Default rule: Avoid transferring PD to jurisdictions without adequate protections.
When necessary: apply safeguards � regulator approvals, standard contractual clauses, Binding Corporate Rules or equivalent contractual commitments; document transfer legal basis in data map.
Data localisation: where permitted/required, use local processing and storage.

11. Training, Awareness and Culture
Mandatory privacy & security training for all staff at onboarding and annually; rolebased advanced training for engineers, ops and customer support.
Simulations: tabletop breach exercises quarterly; phishing exercises for staff.
Reporting channels: anonymous reporting for suspected misuse with no retaliation.

12. Monitoring, Audit and Continuous Improvement
KPIs: % of data mapped; DPIAs completed for highrisk features; mean time to detect (MTTD) and mean time to respond (MTTR) for incidents; DSAR SLA compliance; encryption coverage.
Audits: quarterly internal technical audits and annual external privacy/security audits (include PCI attestation where applicable).
Policy review cadence: Policy and data map reviewed at least annually or after significant legal/architectural change.

13. Implementation Roadmap (90 days, prioritized)
Days 1�14
Appoint DPO/privacy lead and form Privacy Steering Committee.
Start live data inventory and classification; list all processors and payment flows.
Run urgent PCI DSS gap check on payments.
Days 15�45
Deploy RBAC, MFA for admin access; encrypt PII in transit and at rest; enable DB audit logging.
Publish user privacy notice and consent UI; implement consent storage.
Begin DPIAs for GPS telemetry and KYC.
Days 46�75
Integrate DSAR workflows (support portal + templates); implement retention automation for lowrisk data.
Vendor contractual updates and security questionnaires completed for top 10 vendors.
Implement SIEM alerting for abnormal DB access; schedule first tabletop breach exercise.
Days 76�90
Complete remediation actions from DPIAs; finalize backup encryption and tested restore.
Run internal audit of access rights; remediate excessive privileges.
Produce regulatorready documentation pack (data map, DPIAs, breach plan, vendor register).
14. Practical Controls Checklist (quick)
Enforce RBAC + MFA; periodic access review.
TLS everywhere; AES256 at rest; KMS for keys.
Parameterised queries + ORM protections; secrets management.
PCI tokenisation for cards; avoid storing CVV.
Centralised SIEM and immutable audit logs.
Vendor contracts with processors� obligations.
DSAR UI, verification workflow and SLA tracking.
DPIA template and signoff process for new features.

15. KPIs and Success Metrics
100% of critical data elements mapped within 30 days.
0 unresolved highrisk findings after 90 days from DPIAs.

  2132→Design goals and trade-offs (pick these first)
  2133→Consistency vs availability: choose strong consistency for financial/booking flows; choose eventual for telemetry and bulk ingest.
  2134→Latency vs durability: local writes (edge) reduce latency but need robust sync/merge strategies.
  2135→Operational complexity vs vendor lock-in: managed cloud services reduce ops but increase coupling; distributed DBs add ops burden.
  2136→Cost predictability vs elasticity: provisioned clusters cost more but are predictable; serverless scales but can spike costs.

  2141→Redundancy: Synchronous or semi-synchronous replicas within region; async cross-region replicas for DR.

  2143→Telemetry and trip logs (high-write ingest)

  2158→Redundancy patterns and how to implement them
  2159→Multi-AZ replication: ensures single data-center failure tolerance; combine with automated failover and health probes.
  2160→Multi-region replication: protects against region-level outages; choose async replication for cross-region to avoid latency impact.
  2161→Synchronous vs asynchronous replication: use sync inside region for zero data loss; use async cross-region to limit write latency.
  2162→Quorum and replication factor: tune RF >= 3 for Cassandra; configure write/read quorums to balance durability vs availability.
  2163→Read replicas and promotion: use read replicas for scale and a safe promotion path (avoid split-brain with fencing / leader leases).
  2164→Backup + PITR: schedule frequent incremental snapshots, weekly fulls, and test restores quarterly.
  2165→Blue/Green and failover playbooks: automate DNS TTL reductions, traffic shifting, and runbooked DB promotion steps.

Use the roles and cadence already in your operating model (Finance Lead, Ops Lead, Procurement Lead, Fleet Manager, PM, GC/CCO for legal/insurance items).
  2599→Goals and principles
  2600→Goals: capture all operational costs accurately; allocate costs by route, vehicle, city zone and product line; detect overruns early; support pricing, forecasting and insurer/audit evidence.
  2601→Principles: single source of truth for transactions; timely (weekly) reconciliation; role-based approvals; granular tagging (trip, vehicle, supplier, cost type); immutable evidence for audits.
  2602→Core categories to track (mandatory tags)
  2603→Fleet: fuel, maintenance, tires, spare parts, depreciation, lease payments, parking, tolls.
  2604→People: driver wages, benefits, training, recruitment, incentives.
  2605→Platform & Tech: hosting, maps/routing fees, SMS/calls, payments fees, software subscriptions, CLM/LMS line items.
  2606→Operations: dispatch costs, call centre, rider refunds, driver incentives, cleaning.
  2607→Insurance & Legal: motor/public liability premiums, D&O, cyber, claims, retainer fees.
  2608→Procurement & Supplies: uniforms, PPE, office supplies, charging/energy for EVs.
  2609→Regulatory & Licensing: permits, inspections, fines and renewals.
  2610→Marketing & Commercial: promos, corporate account discounts, partnerships.
  2611→Contingency & Claims: incident payouts, customer remediation, arbitration/legal settlements.
  2612→Always tag each expense with: date, invoice number, vendor, GL code, project/trip ID (if applicable), vehicle ID, zone/city, and approval owner.
  2613→Tools and data flows
  2614→Use a cloud accounting system (e.g., Xero, QuickBooks) integrated with:

  2616→Fleet management telematics (automatically log fuel, vehicle km, service events).

  2620→Expense capture process (day-to-day)
  2621→Capture: vendor invoices, driver claims, card transactions, and payment batches enter system within 3 business days. Mobile receipts must be uploaded within 24 hours.
  2622→Auto-tagging: apply vendor ? category rules; telematics feed auto-attach vehicle ID and km to fuel/maintenance lines.
  2623→Manual review: Finance reviewer inspects exceptions and untagged items daily.
  2624→Approval: owner-level approval for expenses above thresholds (e.g., >ETB X) before payment. Approvals routed through accounting tool.
  2625→Reconciliation: weekly bank and card reconciliation; match payments to invoices and trips.
  2626→Archive: store PDF scans and contracts with immutable timestamps; link to expense line.

  2628→Direct allocation: tie fuel, maintenance, and driver wages to vehicle and trip IDs for per-trip costing.

  2879→Fleet management software � shortlist and recommendation (free-first)
  2880→Below are 12 fleet management software options (free or low-cost prioritized), summarize their selling points, where they beat the market, limitations for Shuttle Plus in Ethiopia, and a clear recommendation with an implementation path.
  2881→
  2882→Shortlist (12 products; free / open-source options first)
  2883→Traccar (open-source, free)
  2884→OpenGTS / OpenFleet (open-source, free)
  2885→Odoo Fleet (community edition � free core)
  2886→FleetOps / FleetSharp (low-cost options / local vendors vary)
  2887→GPSWOX (freemium)
  2888→Fleetio (paid; free trial)

  2890→Verizon Connect (paid; enterprise)
  2891→Teletrac Navman (paid; enterprise)
  2892→KeepTruckin / Motive (paid; strong dashcam/ELD integration)
  2893→GpsGate (hosted or self-hosted; flexible pricing)
  2894→CalAmp / Mix Telematics (paid; regional presence)
  2895→
  2896→Quick one-line positioning
  2897→Traccar: Best no-cost GPS tracking and self-hosting control.
  2898→OpenGTS: Classic open-source telematics platform for full customization.
  2899→Odoo Fleet: Lightweight fleet module as part of a wider ERP (free community edition).
  2900→GPSWOX: Freemium option with quick setup and mobile apps.
  2901→Fleetio: Excellent fleet lifecycle, maintenance, and procurement workflows.
  2902→Samsara: Full-stack telematics + dashcams + analytics at scale.
  2903→Verizon Connect / Teletrac / CalAmp: Enterprise-grade reliability, compliance, and support.
  2904→KeepTruckin/Motive: Strong on compliance, driver safety, and dashcams.
  2905→GpsGate: Flexible self-hosted or cloud; good for integrators.
  2906→FleetOps/FleetSharp: Regional/SMB-focused solutions with local support.
  2907→
  2908→Feature comparison (what matters to Shuttle Plus)
  2909→GPS tracking & live location � essential for airport ETAs. Traccar, GpsGate, Samsara, and Fleetio provide strong solutions (Traccar/GpsGate allow self-hosting).
  2910→Maintenance & TCO workflows � Fleetio and Odoo Fleet excel at maintenance scheduling, parts, and procurement.
  2911→Driver behavior & safety (harsh braking, speeding) � Samsara, Motive, and Verizon Connect have mature driver scoring and dashcam integrations.
  2912→Offline / low-connectivity support � Traccar (self-hosted) and Odoo can be tuned for intermittent connectivity; many enterprise cloud platforms struggle without reliable mobile networks.
  2913→Integration & APIs � GpsGate, Traccar, Fleetio, and Samsara offer robust APIs for booking apps and dispatch systems.
  2914→Cost & deployment flexibility � Open-source (Traccar, OpenGTS) and Odoo Community provide lowest licensing cost; hosted enterprise solutions carry high recurring fees.
  2915→Local payments, SMS/WhatsApp, mobile-money events � Most open platforms allow custom integrations; SaaS vendors may require paid connectors.
  2916→Dashcam and video telematics � Samsara, Motive, and CalAmp are leaders; costly but valuable for claims and safety.
  2917→Multi-tenant / partner fleet governance � GpsGate and some enterprise platforms support multi-tenant accounts for franchise/partner oversight.
  2918→
  2919→Where each option beats the market (concise)
  2920→Traccar � unbeatable price (free), self-hosting, and support for many GPS devices; best for bootstrapped operations that want full data control.
  2921→OpenGTS � mature open stack for custom telematics; good for integrations but requires heavy dev.
  2922→Odoo Fleet � best if you already plan to use Odoo ERP for HR, accounting and operations; low-cost integration across modules.
  2923→Fleetio � market-leading maintenance workflows, audits, inspections, and inventory tracking.
  2924→GpsGate � flexible deployment; strong multi-tenant and reseller features for partner fleets.
  2925→Samsara � best-in-class telematics + video + analytics; premium pricing but reduces claims and improves safety rapidly.
  2926→Motive / KeepTruckin � best where driver compliance and video evidence are primary concerns.
  2927→Verizon Connect / Teletrac / CalAmp � strong enterprise SLAs, regional support, and compliance for large-scale ops.
  2928→
  2929→Best fit for Shuttle Plus (recommended stack and why)
  2930→Recommendation: Start with a hybrid stack combining Traccar (self-hosted) or GpsGate (self-hosted/cloud) for real-time tracking + Odoo Community for fleet & maintenance workflows, then selectively add paid telematics/dashcam services (Samsara or Motive) for specific high-value vehicles.
  2931→Why this combination works for Shuttle Plus in Ethiopia:
  2932→Cost-sensitive: Traccar + Odoo Community has minimal licensing cost and avoids heavy recurring SaaS fees.
  2933→Control & data sovereignty: Self-hosting keeps location and passenger-related telemetry under company control and avoids costly international bandwidth/SaaS contracts.
  2934→Offline resilience: Open platforms can be configured for intermittent mobile connectivity and local SMS/WhatsApp integration for ETAs.
  2935→Modular scale: Start small (GPS tracking + inspections) and add premium telematics/dashcams for core corporate or high-liability routes only.
  2936→Integration with existing operations: Odoo gives a lightweight route into HR, maintenance, asset management, and invoicing without building an entire ERP from scratch.
  2937→Partner governance: GpsGate or Traccar + custom dashboards allow multi-tenant views to audit partner/franchise fleets.
  2938→
  2939→Implementation plan (practical, phased)
  2940→Phase 0 � Decisions and procurement (Week 0�2)
  2941→Choose primary tracking platform (Traccar or GpsGate) and confirm hosting (on-prem server in Addis or low-cost cloud region).
  2942→Choose Odoo Community for fleet/maintenance or evaluate Fleetio paid plan if budget allows.
  2943→Phase 1 � Pilot (Week 2�8)
  2944→Equip 10�15 core vehicles with reliable GPS trackers (Teltonika, Queclink, Meitrack are common and supported).
  2945→Deploy Traccar (self-host) and connect devices; configure geofences for Bole Airport, hotels, and hubs.
  2946→Set up Odoo Fleet: vehicle records, maintenance schedules, DVIR templates, and driver profiles.
  2947→Integrate basic webhook/API between booking app and Traccar for live ETAs and SMS/WhatsApp alerts.
  2948→Phase 2 � Expand & add governance (Week 8�16)
  2949→Add analytics dashboards: utilization, on-time pickup rate, idle time, and geofence breaches.
  2950→Onboard partner fleets with multi-tenant views; enforce vehicle acceptance checklist via Odoo inspections.
  2951→Run 90-day QA and maintenance KPI review; adjust trackers and workflows.
  2952→Phase 3 � Add premium telematics where needed (Quarter 2�4)
  2953→For corporate contracts, add Samsara or Motive devices/dashcams on assigned vehicles; use their safety analytics for incentive programs.
  2954→Add automated incident evidence flow: dashcam clips attached to incident tickets in Odoo.
  2955→
  2956→Costs and device notes (practical guidance)
  2957→GPS trackers: basic Teltonika/Queclink units (LTE/GPS) cost ~USD 30�90 per device; choose models with battery backup.
  2958→Hosting: a small cloud instance for Traccar can run ~USD 10�40/month; on-prem adds hardware CAPEX but reduces foreign recurring costs.
  2959→Odoo Community: free for software; expect implementation time and modest hosting costs; paid Odoo apps or consultants add cost.
  2960→Samsara/Motive: device + subscription per vehicle can be costly (USD tens/month); reserve for high-value assets.
  2961→
  2962→Risks and mitigations
  2963→Device theft / tampering � use tamper alerts, VIN registration, and immobilizer integration where possible.
  2964→Mobile connectivity gaps � configure trackers to store data offline and upload when connected; use SMS-based fallback for ETA notifications.
  2965→Local support � prioritize vendors with local partners or reliable remote setup guides; plan for spare device inventory.
  2966→Data privacy / regulatory � store audit logs, anonymize PII when not needed, and document local compliance for airport/transport regulators.

  2969→Fleet strategy overview
  2970→Shuttle Plus manages fleet across small, large, and seasonal scenarios with a single unified playbook that emphasizes modular capacity, cost predictability, safety, and rapid scalability. The playbook has three pillars: Rightsizing (match capacity to demand), Resilience (maintenance, backups, supplier diversity), and Operational agility (datadriven dispatch, dynamic rostering, rapid onboarding/offboarding of vehicles and drivers).
  2971→1. Small fleet scenario (up to ~25 vehicles)
  2972→Organizational model

  2974→Multiskilling: Drivers perform basic checks; one oncall technician for repairs.

  2977→Prefer owned vehicles for reliability; hold 1�2 leased backups.

  2980→Spare pool: 1 dedicated spare vehicle; rotate to avoid age clustering.
  2981→Operations
  2982→Central dispatch with manual surge rules; simple routing templates (airport, hotel loops).
  2983→Fixed rosters with floaters to cover sick leave and peak windows.
  2984→Cost controls
  2985→Tight fuel tracking, consolidated supplier invoicing, simple telematics for fuel and idling metrics.
  2986→KPI targets
  2987→Availability ? 92%; ontime pickup ? 90%; preventive compliance 100%.
  2988→2. Large fleet scenario (25�200+ vehicles)
  2989→Organizational model
  2990→Distributed hubs: multiple dispatch hubs; Hub Managers, Fleet Supervisors, Maintenance Team, Regional Planner.
  2991→Dedicated teams: procurement, parts inventory, training, QA.
  2992→Procurement & composition
  2993→Diversified mix: minibuses, 12�18 seat shuttles, sedans, and a small number of larger coaches for bulk runs.
  2994→Blend of ownership and longterm leases to optimize capex vs opex.
  2995→Maintenance & lifecycle
  2996→Tiered maintenance program: daily driver checks, weekly shop checks, mileage/time based services, scheduled midlife refurb.
  2997→Inhouse workshop for routine work; external authorized partners for heavy repairs. Central parts inventory with reorder automation.

  2999→Advanced dispatch platform with dynamic routing, load balancing across hubs, and automated peak rules.
